thread.title: NL Championship Series capsule: Cubs vs. Mets
thread.title_full: NL Championship Series capsule: Cubs vs. Mets

title: NL Championship Series capsule: Cubs vs. Mets
text:
USA TODAY Sports' Ted Berg previews the National League Championship Series. USA TODAY Sports
Cubs third baseman Kris Bryant and first baseman Anthony Rizzo celebrate winning the NLDS. (Photo: Jerry Lai, USA TODAY Sports)
1 CONNECT 2 NEW YORK — A capsule look at the National League Championship Series between the Chicago Cubs and New York Mets:
Time/TV/Probable Pitchers
Game 1: Cubs (Jon Lester, 11-12, 3.34 ERA) at Mets (Matt Harvey, 13-8, 2.71 ERA), Saturday, 8:07 p.m. ET on TBS
Game 2: Cubs (Jake Arrieta, 22-6, 1.77) at Mets (Noah Syndergaard 9-7, 3.24, or Steven Matz, 4-0, 2.27), Sunday, 8:07 p.m. ET on TBS
Game 3: Mets (Jacob deGrom, 14-8, 2.54) at Cubs (Kyle Hendricks, 8-7, 3.95 ERA), Tuesday, 8:07 p.m. ET on TBS
Game 4: Mets (Syndergaard or Matz) at Cubs (Jason Hammel, 10-7, 3.74 ERA), Wednesday, 8:07 p.m. on TBS
Game 5*: Mets (Harvey) at Cubs (Lester), Thursday, 8:07 p.m. on TBS
Game 6*: Cubs (Arrieta) at Mets (Syndergaard or Matz), Saturday, 4:07** p.m. on TBS
Game 7*: Cubs (Hendricks) at Mets (deGrom), Sunday, 8:07 p.m. on TBS
(*if necessary; **will move to 8:07 if ALCS is complete)
***
USA TODAY
The Walkoff Podcast: Previewing the NLCS between the Cubs, Mets
The case for the Mets: New York has the most exciting, hardest-throwing cadre of young pitchers in baseball. Matt Harvey, Noah Syndergaard, Jacob deGrom and Steven Matz are all between the ages of 22 and 27 and contributed to the Mets throwing, by far, the most pitches in baseball of 95 miles per hour or higher. The rotation’s overall strikeout rate was weighed down by the inclusion of Bartolo Colon and Jon Niese in the staff for 60 starts, but the four pitchers who’ll get the ball to start games in this series had a 2.77 season ERA and struck out 9.4 hitters per nine innings, an unprecedented rate for a rotation. That bodes well against a Cubs lineup that struck out 126 more times than any other club in the majors and batted .228 against 95+ pitches, which ranked 23rd in the majors. (Pitch speed and result data from BaseballSavant.com .)
On July 23, the Mets started a lineup whose 2-through-6 hitters were Ruben Tejada, Wilmer Flores, John Mayberry Jr. and Eric Campbell — a heart of the order that would disappoint spring training fans. The next day, the Mets traded for Kelly Johnson and Juan Uribe, and they of course added Yoenis Cespedes, who’d hit 17 HRs in 57 games, a week later. As a result, the Mets went from the worst-scoring offense in the NL through July 23 but the highest-scoring offense since July 24 with 77 home runs in their first 96 games and 100 homers in their final 66 games. The additions weren’t the only aid: Daniel Murphy and Curtis Granderson quietly played well all season, while rookie Michael Conforto impressed after his promotion and David Wright returned after missing most of the season with injury.
***
The case for the Cubs: Chicago has a dynamic young offense — their starting infield this season of Anthony Rizzo, Starlin Castro, Addison Russell and Kris Bryant was the first group all 25 and younger since 1942 and only the eighth in history, with the 1911 Philadelphia Athletics and 1928 Yankees winning World Series titles. Russell will miss this series with a hamstring injury, but the Cubs can slot in Javier Baez, 22, at shortstop, and they also have two mashing corner outfielders in Kyle Schwarber and Jorge Soler, ages 22 and 23.
That offense led the majors in walks and strikeouts and helped the Cubs win 97 games, the most among the remaining four teams. Starter Jake Arrieta had arguably the greatest second half in baseball history, going 12-1 with a 0.75 ERA and two shutouts. He’ll get the ball twice, as will be lefthander Jon Lester, who had a 3.34 ERA after signing a $155-million free-agent contract last winter; Lester has a 2.57 ERA in 13 career postseason starts with two World Series rings with the Red Sox.
FOR THE WIN
How they're built: The construction and contributions of the MLB's four LCS teams
***
The X factor: Shortstop play will loom large, as both clubs are missing their starting shortstops: the Cubs’ Russell with a hamstring injury and the Mets’ Ruben Tejada with a broken leg suffered during Chase Utley’s instantly infamous slide. New York will turn to Wilmer Flores, who actually started more games at short (96) during the season, although Tejada started the first two NLDS games. Flores is seen as the inferior defender and an inconsistent hitter, but he has power: he slugged 16 homers this season.
Chicago will use Baez, who’s an exaggerated version of Flores: his legendary bat speed generates even more power — he’s hit as many as 37 homers in a minor league season — but he has struck out in 38% of career plate appearances and also can be inconsistent in the field.
Overall, both clubs both rated highly as fielding units: the Mets and Cubs were a hair apart as the third- and fourth-ranked units by Baseball Prospectus’ park-adjusted defensive efficiency.
***
Close and late: Both clubs have reliable closers. The Mets’ Jeurys Familia had 43 saves in 48 chances with a 1.85 ERA in 78 innings; he also retired all 16 batters he faced in the NLDS. Hector Rondon locks down the ninth inning for the Cubs, having gone 30-for-34 in save opportunities with a 1.67 ERA in 71 innings.
Chicago has more bullpen depth, with starters-turned-relievers Travis Wood, Clayton Richard and Trevor Cahill provide middle-inning help with both arms, leading up to Pedro Strop and Justin Grimm, who both had dominant seasons with high strikeout rates. Manager Joe Maddon has always run a good bullpen, putting pitchers in position to succeed.
New York has two set-up men with proven track records but recent inconsistency in Tyler Clippard and Addison Reed as wild cards. Former starter Jon Niese is the only lefty in the bullpen, whereas another former rotation member, Bartolo Colon, can he be helpful as he was used in the NLDS as a multi-inning bridge.
***
In the end: Since the beginning of August, the Cubs went 42-18 (.700) and the Mets were 37-22 (.627), the first and third best records in the NL, so these are two clubs that peaked late — but the Mets have more rotation depth, home-field advantage and better history on their side.
METS IN 7
GALLERY: TOP MOMENTS IN THE POSTSEASON
Facebook Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Best moments of the 2015 MLB postseason Fullscreen Post to Facebook Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed.
ALCS Game 1: Royals vs. Blue Jays - SS Troy Tulowitzki turns a huge inning-ending double play with 2B Ryan Goins to save a run in the sixth. Peter Aiken, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen ALCS Game 1: Royals vs. Blue Jays - Royals starter Edinson Volquez stifles Blue Jays hitters over six innings and allows just two hits. Peter Aiken, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen NLDS Game 5: Mets vs. Dodgers - Daniel Murphy blasts a solo home run in the sixth inning to give the Mets a 3-2 lead. Richard Mackson, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen ALDS Game 5: Astros vs. Royals - Johnny Cueto retires the last 19 batters he faces in Game 5 as the Royals advance to the ALCS. Denny Medley, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen ALDS Game 5: Astros vs. Royals - Alex Rios hits a two-run double in the fifth inning to give the Royals a 4-2 lead. John Rieger, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen ALDS Game 5: Astros vs. Royals - Lorenzo Cain scores from first on a Eric Hosmer single to center in the fourth inning. Peter Aiken, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen ALDS Game 5: Rangers vs. Blue Jays - Jose Bautista gives the Blue Jays a 6-3 lead in the seventh inning with a three-run home run. Nick Turchiaro, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen ALDS Game 5: Rangers vs. Blue Jays - Home plate umpire Dale Scott signals for Rangers' Rougned Odor to score after conferring with the base umpires to confirm an error by Blue Jays catcher Russell Martin on a play in the seventh inning. Martin's toss back to Aaron Sanchez hits Sin-Shoo Choo's bat and Odor scores from third base. Frank Gunn, AP Fullscreen ALDS Game 5: Rangers vs. Rangers: Edwin Encarnacion ties the game 2-2 with a home run in the sixth inning. Tom Szczerbowski, Getty Images Fullscreen ALDS Game 5: Rangers vs. Blue Jays - Center fielder Kevin Pillar makes a diving catch to rob Josh Hamilton of a hit in the fourth inning. Dan Hamilton, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen ALDS Game 5: Rangers vs. Blue Jays - Pillar shows the ball in front of teammate Ben Revere. Tom Szczerbowski, Getty Images Fullscreen NLDS Game 4: Dodgers vs. Mets - Pitching on only three days’ rest for the third time in his career, Clayton Kershaw allows just three hits over seven innings and strikes out eight in the process. Brad Penner, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen NLDS Game 4: Cubs vs. Cardinals - Kyle Schwarber crushes his third homer of the series -- this one lands atop the RF video board. David Banks, Getty Images Fullscreen NLDS, Game 4: Cubs vs. Cardinals - Anthony Rizzo hits a solo home run in the sixth inning to give the Cubs a 5-4 lead in the elimination game. Jerry Lai, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen NLDS Game 4: Cubs vs. Cardinals - Cubs' Javier Baez rounds the bases after a three-run home run in the second inning. Jerry Lai, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen NLDS Game 3: Mets vs. Dodgers - Yoenis Cespedes hits a moonshot 440 feet to give the Mets a 10-3 lead. Andy Marlin, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen NLDS Game 3: Mets vs. Dodgers - After suffering a season-ending injury in Game 2, Ruben Tejada takes the field for player introductions to a standing ovation at Citi Field. Anthony Gruppuso, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen NLDS Game 3: Cubs vs. Cardinals - The Cubs become the first team in baseball history to have four players under the age of 27 with homers in a postseason game. They have five. They are - Kyle Schwarber, who hits a solo home run in the second inning. Jerry Lai, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen NLDS Game 3: Cubs vs. Cardinals - Starlin Castro hits a homer in the fourth inning. Jerry Lai, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen NLDS Game 3: Cubs vs. Cardinals - Kris Bryant hits a two-run home run in the fifth inning. Jerry Lai, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen NLDS Game 3: Cubs vs. Cardinals - Anthony Rizzo hits a homer in the fifth inning. Jerry Lai, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen NLDS Game 3: Cubs vs. Cardinals - Jorge Soler's hits a two-run homer in the sixth inning. Jerry Lai, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen NLDS Game 3: Cubs vs. Cardinals - Dexter Fowler hits a homer in the eighth inning. Dennis Wierzbicki, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen ALDS Game 4: Rangers vs. Blue Jays: Josh Donaldson hits a towering two-run home run in the first inning to give the Jays the lead. Tim Heitman, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen ALDS Game 4: Astros vs. Royals - The Royals stroke five consecutive singles to spark a five-run rally in the eighth-inning, wiping out a four-run deficit. Thomas Shea, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen ALDS Game 4: Astros vs. Royals - The Astros dugout can't bear to watch as the Royals score five runs in the eighth inning. Thomas Shea, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen ALDS Game 4: Astros vs. Royals - Astros' Carlos Correa blasts his second home run -- a two-run homer to give the Astros a 5-2 lead in the 7th inning. Thomas Shea, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen ALDS, Game 3: Blue Jays vs. Rangers: Troy Tulowitzki smashes a three-run home run in the 6th inning to give the Blue Jays a 5-0 lead. Tim Heitman, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen ALDS Game 3: Astros vs. Royals -- After setting a record for most wins by pitcher who went unbeaten at home in a season, Astros ace Dallas Keuchel improves on his 15-0 ledger at Minute Maid Park this year. Thomas Shea, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen NLDS Game 2: Mets vs. Dodgers -- SS Ruben Tejada collides with Chase Utley at second base in the seventh inning. Jayne Kamin-Oncea, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen NLDS Game 2: Mets vs. Dodgers - Rookie Michael Conforto hits a laser off Zack Greinke for a home run that had an exit velocity of 115 mph. Jayne Kamin-Oncea, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen NLDS Game 2: Cubs vs. Cardinals. Cubs shortstop Addison Russell squares for a suicide squeeze in the second inning -- the second of the inning. Jeff Curry, \USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen NLDS Game 2: Cubs vs. Cardinals - Matt Carpenter leads off the game with s solo home run. Jasen Vinlove, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen NLDS Game 1: Mets vs. Dodgers - David Wright's two-run single in the 7th inning gives the Mets a 3-0 lead. Richard Mackson, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen NLDS Game 1: Mets vs. Dodgers - Jacob deGrom strikes out 13 batters, which ties Tom Seaver for most strikeouts by a Mets pitcher in postseason history. Jayne Kamin-Oncea, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen NLDS Game 1: Cubs vs. Cardinals - Cardinals rookie Tommy Pham, a career minor leaguer, homers in his first postseason game, 431 feet. Scott Rovak, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen NLDS Game 1: Cubs vs. Cardinals - John Lackey, who took a no-hitter into the six inning, allows just two hits over 7 1/3 innings. Scott Rovak, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen ALDS Game 2: Astros vs. Royals - Astros' Colby Rasmus hits a home run against the Royals -- his third homer in three straight postseason games. Peter Aiken, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen ALDS Game 2: Rangers vs. Blue Jays - Blue Jays slugger Josh Donaldson get into a shouting match with Rangers reliever Keone Kela in the 13th inning, causing the benches and benches to briefly empty. Nick Turchiaro, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen ALDS Game 2: Rangers vs. Blue Jays - Hansel Alberto, not pictured, lines a 14th-inning, game-winning single to center, plating Rougned Odor, pictured, as the Rangers take a 2-0 series lead over the Blue Jays. . Nick Turchiaro, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen ALDS Game 2: Rangers vs. Blue Jays - Rougned Odor makes an elusive slide past the tag of Blue Jays catcher Russell Martin in the second inning to give the Rangers a 3-1 lead. Dan Hamilton, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen ALDS Game 1: Astros vs. Royals - Center fielder Jake Marisnick makes a diving catch in the fifth inning to rob Royals' Elcides Escobar. John Rieger, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen ALDS Game 1: Rangers vs. Blue Jays - Rougned Odor (right) celebrates with Delino DeShields after hitting a solo home run in the 7th inning to give the Rangers a deciding 5-3 lead. Nick Turchiaro, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen NL wild-card game: The Cubs celebrate their first postseason win since the 2003 NLCS after defeating the Pirates 4-0. Charles LeClaire, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen NL wild-card game: Jake Arrieta becomes the first Cubs pitcher to throw a postseason shutout in 70 years, leading the Cubs to a 4-0 victory. Charles LeClaire, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen NL wild-card game: Cubs rookie Kyle Schwarber rounds the bases after hitting a majestic 450-foot two-run homer that landed in the Allegheny River in the third inning off Pirates' Gerrit Cole. Charles LeClaire, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen NL wild-card game: Cubs starter Jake Arrieta reacts after he was hit by a pitch by Pirates' Tony Watson in the seventh inning. "It’s the playoffs.There’s a lot at stake. Tempers are running hot. It’s just the environment. It breeds that kind of intensity, and sometimes those things happen." Charles LeClaire, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen AL wild-card game: On three days rest, Dallas Keuchel hurls six shutout innings of three-hit, seven-strikeout ball in Houston’s 3-0 victory over the Yankees. Adam Hunger, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen AL wild-card game: Astros outfielder Carlos Gomez hits a home run on the first pitch of the fourth inning off Yankees' Masahiro Tanaka that sails deep into the left field stands, silencing the capacity crowd. Appropriately, Gomez flips his bat and admires it. Adam Hunger, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen Like this topic?
